Adjunct Faculty — Cyber Threat Intelligence

University of Maryland (UMD). I teach hands‑on Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) with a focus on tradecraft, analytic rigor, and operational relevance. On this page you’ll find my syllabus, office hours, and curated CTI resources for students and practitioners.

MITRE ATT&CK STIX/TAXII YARA & Sigma Threat Hunting Intel Analysis

About

I’m an adjunct faculty member at the University of Maryland with professional experience in software engineering, defense, and cyber operations. My teaching emphasizes analytic tradecraft, structured techniques, and the translation of intelligence into action for SOCs, hunt teams, and leadership.

Areas of Interest

  • Threat group analysis & attribution caveats
  • Building and defending secure software applications
  • Collection strategies & bias mitigation
  • Production workflows, PIRs, and stakeholder mapping
  • Detection engineering from intel (ATT&CK → Sigma/YARA)

Teaching

Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI)

Outcomes: Students learn to plan collection, analyze intrusion sets, communicate decision‑quality intel, and produce detections informed by ATT&CK.

Topics: Kill Chain & ATT&CK, CTI lifecycle, STIX/TAXII, malware triage, campaign analysis, reporting & briefing, detection engineering, ethics & law.

CTI Resources

Practitioner Toolkit

  • MITRE ATT&CK — Tactics, techniques, and procedures
  • STIX/TAXII — Data models & transport for intel
  • MISP — Open‑source threat intel platform
  • YARA & Sigma — Detection rules
  • ATT&CK Navigator — Layered technique mapping

Reading

  • Analysis of Competing Hypotheses (ACH)
  • Structured analytic techniques for intelligence
  • Hunt team case studies and DFIR write‑ups
